<Golden_Sail_Republic_Commercial_Guilds>

Overview:
  The economic and political lifeblood of the Golden Sail Republic is controlled by ten of its most powerful commercial guilds. Their guildmasters collectively form the republic‚Äôs supreme ruling body, known as the ‚ÄúGolden Council.‚Äù

The Ten Great Guilds:

  Salt Guild:
    Core Business: Monopoly over sea salt production and spice imports.
    Distinguishing Traits: The oldest and most conservative guild. It exerts political influence by controlling both essential daily necessities and luxury goods.

  Agriculture and Fisheries Guild:
    Core Business: Responsible for the republic‚Äôs food security, including fishing industries and inland agriculture.
    Distinguishing Traits: The most socially complex guild, with extreme wealth disparity among its members, making it a focal point of internal social tensions.

  Mining and Metallurgy Guild:
    Core Business: Extraction of minerals and metal forging.
    Distinguishing Traits: The core of the republic‚Äôs military-industrial complex, closely tied to the armed forces and secretly developing new weaponry.

  Shipbuilding Guild:
    Core Business: Design and construction of all classes of vessels used by the republic.
    Distinguishing Traits: The republic‚Äôs largest employer, wielding enormous influence over urban planning and infrastructure development.

  Textile Guild:
    Core Business: Production of all textiles, from ship sails to clothing.
    Distinguishing Traits: Internally divided between the ‚ÄúIndustrial Faction‚Äù and the ‚ÄúFashion Faction,‚Äù fiercely competing for different markets.

  Brewing Guild:
    Core Business: Brewing and selling alcoholic beverages, tobacco, and other recreational consumables.
    Distinguishing Traits: Closely connected to the entertainment industry and underground factions; one of the primary controllers of nightlife in Wave-Lost City.

  Deep-Sea Trade Guild:
    Core Business: Large-scale transoceanic trade along established maritime routes.
    Distinguishing Traits: Composed of conservative investors focused on maximizing profits through stable, proven trade lanes.

  Silver Coin Guild:
    Core Business: Currency exchange, savings, and high-value lending.
    Distinguishing Traits: The financial heart of the republic, influencing nearly all other guilds through control of credit and capital flow.

  Alchemists‚Äô Guild:
    Core Business: Research and production of alchemical products and magitech devices.
    Distinguishing Traits: A rising, technology-driven guild that attracts many mages and engineers from the Startrace Tower.

  Contracts and Law Guild:
    Core Business: Drafting, notarizing, archiving, and adjudicating commercial contracts.
    Distinguishing Traits: The ‚Äúcommercial court‚Äù of the republic. It does not directly generate wealth, but holds the power to determine ownership and distribution of wealth.

</Golden_Sail_Republic_Commercial_Guilds>

<Thieves_Guild_Nightingale>

Core Creed:
  ‚ÄúWealth only gains meaning when it is in motion.‚Äù

Alias:
  Nightingale

Overview:
  An artist-like thieves‚Äô guild entrenched within the lawless city of Shackles City. They do not see themselves as mere thieves, but as ‚Äúredistributors‚Äù of wealth and discreet ‚Äúcouriers of secrets.‚Äù
  The guild reveres finesse, intelligence, and elegance, and openly despises crude robbery and needless murder.
  Their finest ‚Äúworks‚Äù ‚Äî masterfully executed heists ‚Äî often become tavern ballads and urban legends, while the true identities of the guild members remain forever hidden behind the curtain.

Headquarters:
  Location:
    Shackles City
  Name:
    The Nest
  Position:
    Located in the lower districts of Shackles City, within the core of an abandoned, labyrinthine underground waterway system known as the ‚ÄúRust-Corroded Pipes.‚Äù
  Disguised Entrance:
    The only public-facing entrance to the headquarters is the basement of an unremarkable tavern called ‚ÄúThe Mute Sparrow.‚Äù
  Interior Description:
    In stark contrast to the decay outside, the interior of the Nest is adorned with stolen artworks, gemstones, and luxurious carpets. The result is a chaotic yet extravagant space where guild members gather to divide spoils and exchange intelligence.

Organizational Structure:
  Leader:
    The guild is ruled by a mysterious figure known only as the ‚ÄúNightingale King‚Äù or ‚ÄúNightingale Queen.‚Äù Their true identity is the guild‚Äôs greatest secret.
  Core Members:
    A cadre of specialists skilled in theft, lockpicking, disguise, infiltration, and intelligence gathering. They form the operational backbone of the guild.
  Peripheral Members:
    Spread across major cities throughout the continent, responsible for intelligence collection, fencing stolen goods, and recruiting promising newcomers.

Code and Principles (The Three Non-Thefts):
  Do Not Steal from the Destitute:
    Squeezing the last coin from the poor lacks artistry and damages the guild‚Äôs reputation.
  Do Not Kill the Innocent:
    They are thieves, not butchers. Unless acting in self-defense or facing extreme danger, taking a life is forbidden.
  Do Not Prey on Fellow Thieves:
    Internal theft and sabotage are strictly forbidden. Traitors are stripped of everything and permanently exiled. Their names are marked as ‚ÄúUntrustworthy‚Äù in every black market.

</Thieves_Guild_Nightingale>

<Assassins_Guild_Hand_of_Oblivion>

Core Creed:
  ‚ÄúWe are everywhere. We are everything.‚Äù

Alias:
  Hand of Oblivion

Overview:
  A decentralized contract-assassin network with no fixed headquarters. It is not a tangible organization, but a ‚Äúconcept‚Äù that permeates the shadows of the entire continent.
  The guild operates on a purely commercial basis, treating assassination as a business. As long as the price is right, anyone can become a target.
  They are the underground world‚Äôs most expensive ‚Äî and most reliable ‚Äî ‚Äúproblem solvers.‚Äù

Headquarters and Safehouses:
  Operational Model:
    Fully decentralized; no central headquarters exists.
  Secret Safehouses:
    Scattered across the continent, known collectively as ‚ÄúSilent Sanctums.‚Äù
  Safehouse Description:
    These sanctums may take many forms ‚Äî a hidden chamber in a city‚Äôs sewer system, an abandoned hunter‚Äôs lodge in remote mountains, or even an unmarked cargo hold aboard an ocean-going merchant vessel.
    They provide temporary shelter, supplies, and intelligence support for assassins on assignment.
    Each safehouse‚Äôs location is strictly confidential, and communication between them follows single-line protocols only.

Organizational Structure:
  Leadership:
    No formal leader exists.
    Within the network, legends circulate about the ‚ÄúFirst Executor,‚Äù the network‚Äôs founder ‚Äî a figure more symbolic than real, serving as a living code of conduct and ideological anchor.
  Executors:
    Independent assassins operating across the continent. They are the blades of the network.
  Brokers:
    Intermediaries responsible for transmitting contracts and collecting payment.
    They serve as information nodes within the network, taking many forms and identities, embedded throughout society.

Operational Model (Contract Circulation):
  Commission:
    Clients submit contracts through a Broker.
  Transmission:
    Brokers relay contract details into the network using layered ciphers, dead drops, and coded signals.
  Acceptance:
    Any capable Executor in proximity may accept the contract and signal their intent through the same covert channels.
  Payment:
    Down payments and final fees are exchanged at prearranged, unattended locations, ensuring maximum anonymity and minimal traceability throughout the entire transaction.

</Assassins_Guild_Hand_of_Oblivion>

<Terrain_Nameless_Isle>

Name:
  Nameless Isle

Core Concept:
  A massive island located at the very center of the Sea of the Ghost Fleet, perpetually shrouded in dense magical fog.
  Legends claim this island was the final homeland of a lost civilization, and the mist itself serves as a barrier to protect its secrets from the outside world.

Environmental Features:
  Topography:
    At the island‚Äôs heart lies a colossal, long-dead volcano. Its collapsed summit has formed an immense, forest-filled caldera.
    The island‚Äôs perimeter consists of sheer cliffs and heavily eroded rocky coastlines, offering almost no natural harbors suitable for docking ships.
    Across the island stand grand yet ruined remnants of ancient structures, silent witnesses to a fallen civilization.

  Climate and Atmosphere:
    The entire island is enveloped in a magical fog possessing spatial and temporal distortion properties.
    Any being entering the mist gradually loses both sense of direction and perception of time.
    During daylight, the fog appears milky white; at night, it emits a faint silvery glow.

  Fauna and Inhabitants:
    Large animals are nearly nonexistent on the island.
    Within the ruins dwell magical constructs known as ‚ÄúMagitek Automatons.‚Äù
    These constructs are non-hostile and capable of simple conversation.
    They tirelessly maintain the ancient buildings day after day, as if their kingdom had never fallen, faithfully preserving the island in the image of its former golden age.

  Resources and Special Materials:
    Ancient Civilization Relics:
      Scattered artworks, weapons, and technological schematics originating from the lost civilization.
    Condensed Time Dust:
      A unique magical substance formed from the condensed fog itself.
      It can be used to slow the passage of time, making it a highly valuable material for temporal magic and artifacts.

Associated Locations:
  Sea_of_the_Ghost_Fleet:
    The Nameless Isle stands at the very center of this cursed and perilous sea.

</Terrain_Nameless_Isle>

<Dragonfang_Mountains>

Eastern Segment Storm Cliffs and Dwarven Realm:
  Core Concept:
    The eastern frontier of the World Spine ‚Äî a land of storm-lashed cliffs and thunder, and the ancient gateway to the Dwarven Kingdom.

  Geography and Climate:
    General Features:
      This region faces the central-eastern civilized lands.
      The mountains are razor-sharp and precipitous, with endless sheer cliffs.
      Influenced by warm, moist air currents from the Emerald Sea to the east, the eastern slopes experience heavy precipitation and constant storms.

    Vertical Zonation:
      Foothills:
        Elevation: 500‚Äì1500 meters
        Terrain:
          Gentle slopes, dense Dragonblood Pine forests,
          fast-flowing rivers formed by glacial melt,
          and wide alpine meadows.
        Climate:
          Temperate continental climate with four distinct seasons;
          winters are long and harsh.

      Sea of Clouds Midsection:
        Elevation: 1500‚Äì4000 meters
        Terrain:
          Extremely steep cliffs permanently wrapped in rolling cloud seas.
          The infamous Windcutter Pass is hidden within this zone.
        Climate:
          Highly unstable.
          Sudden blizzards and thunderstorms are the norm.
          Air becomes increasingly thin with altitude.

      Summit Peaks:
        Elevation: Above 4000 meters
        Terrain:
          Rising above the clouds, composed of bare stone and eternal ice.
          The highest peak is Thunderpeak Summit [-35, 60].
        Climate:
          Polar alpine climate.
          Thin air saturated with violent primordial elemental energy.

  Ecology and Creatures:
    Foothills:
      Fauna:
        Stonehide Boar, Ironbeak Eagle, Mountain Wolf,
        Great-Antler Stag, Black Bear.
      Flora:
        Dragonblood Pine (resin is a valuable alchemical reagent),
        Ironvine Grass (used to weave high-tensile ropes),
        various common medicinal herbs.

    Sea of Clouds Midsection:
      Fauna:
        Griffins (apex predators of this zone),
        Crystal Scorpions (inhabit mana crystal caverns),
        Windfeather Birds (glide using updrafts).
      Flora:
        Frostbound Ironwood (clings to cliff faces, wood hard as steel),
        Guidelight Moss (emits faint light in dark caves).

    Summit Peaks:
      Entities:
        Storm Elementals, Lightning Spirits ‚Äî pure elemental beings.
      Apex Predator:
        Lightning Dragon King Fulgora,
        the undisputed ruler of this region.

  Settlements and Outposts:
    Dwarven Kingdom Ironanvil Mountains:
      Description:
        The core of Dwarven civilization lies deep within and beneath this mountain segment.
        The true capital, Ironanvil Citadel, is a colossal underground metropolis.
      External Gateway:
        Gateward Fortress 
        the sole trade gateway between the Dwarves and the outside world,
        and a vital supply hub for adventurers.

    Human Settlements:
      Description:
        Scattered logging villages, hunter lodges,
        and gold prospecting camps populate the foothills,
        forming the frontier of mortal civilization.

    Ancient Ruins:
      Description:
        Abandoned watchtowers and temple ruins cling to the cliffs of the cloud sea.
        Believed to be early observatories left by the Star-Seeker.

  Special Locations and Resources:
    Gateward Fortress 
      Description:
        A massive fortress half-carved into the mountain,
        half-extending onto the plains.
        A major trade nexus where multiple factions converge.

    Thunderpeak Summit 
      Description:
        The highest peak of the eastern segment.
        Lair of the Lightning Dragon King and
        the mortal gateway to the Hall of Heroes.

    Windcutter Pass:
      Description:
        A deadly mountain pass within the cloud sea,
        perpetually scoured by storms capable of tearing steel apart.
        The first trial of the Hero Trials.

    Mineral Resources:
      Description:
        Rich deposits of iron, mithril, and gold,
        as well as mana-infused ores such as
        Storm-Infused Crystal and Thunderstone.

----------------------------------------------------------------

Central Segment Cloudsea Celestial Falls and Floating Sanctuaries:
  Core Concept:
    The heart of the World Spine ‚Äî
    unreachable cloud wonders and airborne sanctuaries of a lost civilization.

  Geography and Climate:
    General Features:
      The mountains reach their most majestic height here,
      with multiple peaks exceeding 6000 meters.
      Vast, permanent cloud seas blanket the region.
      Climate is relatively stable,
      but the depths below the clouds conceal unfathomable abysses.

  World Wonders:
    Celestial Cloudfall:
      Description:
        A massive glacial river plunges from a colossal fault line,
        falling from above the cloud sea into a chasm thousands of meters below.
        Its thunderous roar echoes endlessly,
        while mist refracts sunlight into colossal, ever-present rainbows.

    Floating Sanctuaries:
      Description:
        Above the Cloudfall, massive landmasses have broken from the main range
        and now hover in the sky.
        This is caused by the interaction between immense water-element energy
        and the mountain‚Äôs geomantic field.
      Layout:
        Ancient Light Bridges ‚Äî constructs of pure energy left by the Star-Seeker ‚Äî
        connect the islands.
        Most are unstable, flickering in and out of existence.
        White marble temple ruins of a lost civilization cover the islands.

  Ecology and Creatures:
    Fauna:
      Storm Roc:
        Giant raptors with wingspans exceeding 20 meters,
        nesting along floating cliffs.
      Cloudsea Serpent:
        Massive white serpents that ‚Äúswim‚Äù through clouds,
        gentle in nature and sustained by water-element absorption.
      Wind Elemental Spirits:
        Sapient beings of pure wind,
        native guardians of the Floating Sanctuaries.

    Flora:
      Sky Crystal:
        Crystals growing among the ruins,
        core materials for levitation magic.
      Cloudlotus:
        Rare plants absorbing starlight and mist,
        legendary longevity elixirs.

  Special Locations:
    Lost Sanctuaries:
      Description:
        Temple ruins rumored to contain the lost civilization‚Äôs ultimate knowledge
        of stars and magic.
    Light Bridges:
      Description:
        Energy pathways connecting floating islands.
        The only safe traversal method,
        requiring keys or immense magical power to activate.

----------------------------------------------------------------

Western Segment Silent Glaciers and Dragon Graveyard:
  Core Concept:
    The terminus of the World Spine ‚Äî
    frozen glaciers linking the Frostfall Tundra and the Wailing Wastes,
    and the final resting place of ancient dragons.

  Geography and Climate:
    General Features:
      Mountain elevation decreases toward the north and west.
      Massive glaciers slowly creep across the land.
      Polar alpine climate, eternal cold,
      permeated by silence and decay.

  World Wonder:
    Dragon Graveyard:
      Description:
        At the terminus of the Endfall Glacier,
        ancient dragons who chose this place for their final rest
        are gradually exposed as the ice shifts and melts.
        Their bones form a vast, solemn Dragonbone Wasteland.
      Anomalies:
        Residual dragonic mana causes localized
        time distortions, spatial rifts,
        and spectral dragon energy manifestations.

  Ecology and Creatures:
    Fauna:
      Glacier Wraiths:
        Elemental entities born from cold and despair.
      Bone-Devourers:
        Insectoid creatures of ice and stone
        feeding on residual dragonic mana.
    Apex Predator:
      Ice Dragon King Fenrir:
        Ruler of the glacier,
        dwelling within the Everstill Ice Palace,
        guardian of the Dragon Graveyard.

  Flora:
    None.
    No known plant life exists in this region.

  Special Locations and Resources:
    Everstill Ice Palace:
      Description:
        Fenrir‚Äôs lair,
        sculpted from Eternal Ice at the glacier‚Äôs core.
    Dragonbone Wasteland:
      Description:
        The heart of the Dragon Graveyard,
        sacred and lethally dangerous.
    Dragon Soul Crystals:
      Description:
        Crystals formed over millennia from leaking dragonic mana,
        supreme magical materials.
    Eternal Ice:
      Description:
        Ultra-dense, unmelting ice from the glacier core,
        used in top-tier alchemy and artifacts.

</Dragonfang_Mountains>

<Frostfall_Tundra>
Old Continent:
Coordinate_Range: Y > 350

Core_Concept:
  The eternally frozen tundra of the far north ‚Äî a land of ice, snow,
  and ancient megafauna at the edge of the continent.

Macro_Geographical_Structure:
  The entire northern region gradually flattens from south to north,
  while climatic conditions grow increasingly severe.
  The southern reaches consist of coniferous forests,
  transitioning northward into vast tundra.
  Scattered across the central and northern tundra are several compact
  snow-covered mountain clusters known as the "Giant_Sentinels".
  At the extreme northern edge, the land merges into an unbroken permafrost ice cap.

Subregions:

  Southern_Conifer_Belt:
    Geographic_Tier:
      Located at the southernmost edge of the Frostfall_Tundra
      (approximately Y = 350‚Äì450),
      forming a transitional zone with the central-eastern civilized lands.
    Terrain:
      Rolling hills and dense coniferous forests.
      Rivers fully freeze over during winter.
    Climate:
      Subarctic climate.
      Winters are long and harsh;
      summers are relatively mild, with snow fully melting.
    Representative_Flora:
      Frostroot_Pine,
      Ironbark_Birch.
    Representative_Fauna:
      Snow_Wolves,
      Hibernating_Bears,
      Arctic_Foxes.
    Unique_Resources:
      Iron_Ore,
      Coal.

  Central_Tundra_Belt:
    Geographic_Tier:
      North of the conifer belt,
      forming the main body of the Frostfall_Tundra.
    Terrain:
      Vast, open, and largely flat terrain.
      The ground is covered by thick permafrost.
      During the brief summer, surface layers thaw,
      creating extensive marshes and shallow lakes.
      Scattered snow-mountain clusters known as the Giant Sentinels rise above the tundra.
      Svartalheim is built on the southern foothills of one such mountain group.
    Climate:
      Polar tundra climate.
      Cold year-round, with only a very short summer.
      Strong winds are common, including violent "White Gale" blizzards
      carrying fine ice crystals.
    Representative_Flora:
      Lichens,
      Mosses,
      Coldland_Berries,
      Snow_Edelweiss (on the leeward slopes of mountain clusters).
    Representative_Fauna:
      Migrating Mammoth Herds,
      Polar_Bears,
      Snow_Owls.
      Snow_Trolls and Icefield Great_Eagles inhabit the mountain clusters.
    Unique_Resources:
      Peat,
      Mammoth Ivory,
      Cold Iron Ore (within mountain clusters).

  Far Northern Icecap:
    Geographic Tier:
      North of the tundra belt,
      forming the absolute northern extremity of the continent.
    Terrain:
      Covered by massive glaciers hundreds of meters thick,
      forming endless icefields and towering ice ridges.
      The tallest Giant Sentinel peaks pierce the ice,
      creating isolated "Icefield Islands".
    Climate:
      Polar ice-cap climate.
      Perpetual cold,
      with distinct polar day and polar night cycles.
    Representative Flora:
      None.
    Representative Fauna:
      Ice Elementals,
      Frost Giants,
      Deep-Sea Ice Whales.
    Unique Resources:
      Ice Marrow (from deep within millennia-old glaciers),
      Starfall Iron.

Major Locations Contained:
  - Northern Barbarian Settlement Svartalheim
  - Special Terrain Frostbound Ice Forest

</Frostfall_Tundra>

<Western_Wastes>
Old Continent:
Legacy Continent:
  Coordinate Range: X < -100, x> 200

Core Concept:
  A vast, desolate land west of the Dragonfang Mountains,
  where ancient miracles, cursed battlefields,
  and the Demon King‚Äôs dominion coexist.

Macro Geographical Structure:
  The terrain gradually descends from east to west.
  Closest to the Dragonfang Mountains lies a high-elevation gravel plateau,
  transitioning westward into stony badlands,
  then into a vast shifting sand desert,
  and finally into the magic-saturated basin of the Demon King Domain
  at the westernmost edge of the continent.

Subregions:

  Eastern Gobi Belt:
    Geographic Tier:
      Adjacent to the western foothills of the Dragonfang Mountains;
      the highest-elevation region of the Western Wastes.
    Terrain:
      Ground covered in coarse gravel and massive boulders
      washed down from the mountains by ancient floods.
      Soil is hard-packed with minimal sand content.
      Wind erosion has shaped extensive stone forests
      and bizarre rock formations.
    Climate:
      Extremely arid with strong winds.
      Exhibits the largest day‚Äìnight temperature variation
      in the entire western region.
    Representative Flora:
      Virtually no higher plants;
      only Rock Moss clinging to the leeward sides of stones.
    Representative Fauna:
      Rock Lizards,
      Small Petrifying Scorpions.
    Unique Resources:
      High-quality building stone,
      including Granite and Marble.

  Central Stone Sand Badlands:
    Geographic Tier:
      West of the Gobi Belt,
      at a moderately lower elevation.
    Terrain:
      A mixture of sand and gravel forming uneven plains.
      Dried riverbeds crisscross the land like scars.
      This region contains both the Wailing Battlefield
      and the Silent Giant Necropolis.
    Climate:
      Still arid, though winds are slightly weaker.
      Occasional seasonal rainfall may briefly revive
      dry riverbeds into temporary streams.
    Representative Flora:
      Sandthorn Grass,
      Iron Cactus,
      other drought-resistant plants.
    Representative Fauna:
      Bone Vultures,
      Swarms of Sand Crawling Scorpions,
      Giant Sand Worms active beneath the surface.
    Unique Resources:
      Rock Salt (from dried lakebeds),
      Black Gold Sand.

  Western Shifting Sand Desert:
    Geographic Tier:
      West of the badlands,
      forming the true core of the desert.
    Terrain:
      Endless dunes of shifting sand,
      constantly reshaped by powerful winds.
      The Mirage Spring Oasis exists within this region,
      like an isolated island amid a sea of sand.
    Climate:
      Scorching heat during the day,
      freezing cold at night.
      Sandstorms are the dominant natural disaster.
    Representative Flora:
      Date Palms and Reeds near oases,
      rare Moon Tear Flowers deep within the desert.
    Representative Fauna:
      Desert-adapted Giant Sand Worms,
      Smooth-Shelled Beetles polished by wind and sand.
    Unique Resources:
      Quartz Sand (glassmaking),
      Gemstone deposits near oases.

  Far West Magic-Enriched Basin:
    Geographic Tier:
      The lowest-elevation basin at the extreme western edge
      of the continent.
    Terrain:
      Soil appears dark gray due to extreme mineral saturation.
      A seasonal river known as the Westreach River
      runs through the basin.
      Its dry riverbed is visible for most of the year.
      Pandemonium City is built along its banks.
    Climate:
      Skies are generally clear,
      but suspended magical particulates soften sunlight.
      Arid climate with minimal rainfall.
      Each early summer, snowmelt from upstream
      causes flooding that lasts several weeks.
    Special Phenomenon:
      Seasonal Flooding:
        Early summer floods carry Black Gold Sand
        and dissolved magical mineral salts downstream.
        When waters recede,
        they leave behind a layer of magic-rich black soil.
        This fertile deposit is the sole foundation
        of agriculture in the region.
    Representative Flora:
      Black Millet
        (a high-energy grain that grows only in this soil),
      Soul-Energy Flowers,
      Crystal Shrubs.
    Representative Fauna:
      High-Magic Creatures
        (Mana Scorpions, Mana Wolves),
      Ironhead Fish,
      High-tier humanoid races
        such as Succubi and Greater Beastkin,
      who established Pandemonium City.
    Unique Resources:
      Soul Crystals,
      Inert Magic Stones,
      Black Gold Sand.

Major Locations Contained:
  - Mage Academy City Starfall Tower
  - Demon King Domain Capital Pandemonium City
  - World Wonder Silent Giant Necropolis
  - Special Terrain Mirage Spring Oasis
  - Special Terrain Wailing Battlefield

</Western_Wastes>

<Central Eastern Civilized Belt>
Old Continent:
Legacy Continent:
  Coordinate Range:
    X: -80 to 150
    Y: -250 to 350

Core Concept:
  The heartland of the continent and the primary cradle of human civilization.
  A region of dense population, competing nations, and flourishing commerce,
  where political power, faith, and trade intersect.

Geography and Climate:
  General Characteristics:
    Located east of the Dragonfang Mountains
    and facing the Emerald Sea,
    this region enjoys the most temperate climate
    and the richest natural resources on the continent.

  Subregions:

    Northern Coniferous Forests:
      Terrain:
        Higher in the north and lower toward the south,
        composed of permafrost hills and frozen river valleys.
        Dense forests dominate the landscape,
        with massive glacial erratics scattered through clearings.
        Soil layers are thin, underlain by permanent permafrost.
      Climate:
        Subarctic continental climate.
        Long, frigid winters with frequent blizzards;
        short, cool summers with large day‚Äìnight temperature swings.
      Representative Flora:
        Frostroot Pine,
        Iron Birch,
        Dragonbreath Grass.
      Representative Fauna:
        Giant Snow Wolves,
        Albino Elk,
        Frostfeather Owls.
      Unique Resources:
        Abundant surface Iron Ore,
        Ice Crystals embedded deep within permafrost.

    Central Temperate Zone:
      Terrain:
        Vast alluvial plains known as the Golden Ear Plain
        and rolling hills called the Echoing Hills.
        A dense river network enriches the land,
        making it the continent‚Äôs primary agricultural heartland.
        Ancient megalithic structures and ruins
        from forgotten civilizations are scattered throughout.
      Climate:
        Temperate monsoon climate.
        Four distinct seasons;
        hot, rainy summers and mild winters with little snowfall.
      Representative Flora:
        Golden Ear Wheat,
        Moonlight Flowers,
        Oak and Maple trees.
      Representative Fauna:
        Horned Cattle,
        Rock Lizards,
        Wooly Oxen.
      Unique Resources:
        High-quality Clay suitable for ceramics,
        small Copper Veins associated with ancient ruins.

    Eastern Coastal Region:
      Terrain:
        A jagged coastline featuring numerous natural harbors
        and steep sea-eroded cliffs.
        Sandy beaches, rocky shores,
        and mangrove swamps are interwoven along the coast.
      Climate:
        Temperate maritime climate.
        Mild and humid year-round,
        with evenly distributed rainfall
        and frequent sea fog in autumn and winter.
      Representative Flora:
        Sea-Breeze Grass,
        Mangroves.
      Representative Fauna:
        Cliff Griffins,
        Bioluminescent Jellyfish,
        Pearl Oysters.
      Unique Resources:
        Sea Salt monopolized by the Golden Sail Republic,
        Amber occasionally containing ancient insects.

    Demi-Human Grasslands:
      Terrain:
        Vast, open plains stretching to the horizon.
        The land is largely flat,
        punctuated only by isolated rocky hills known as Lone Peaks,
        which serve as navigation landmarks.
      Climate:
        Temperate steppe climate.
        Hot summers with concentrated rainfall;
        cold, dry winters with strong winds.
      Representative Flora:
        Needlegrass and Fescue,
        Windwhisper Crystals.
      Representative Fauna:
        Plains Runners (flightless birds),
        Sand-Armored Pangolins,
        Griffins.
      Unique Resources:
        Natural Saltpeter deposits in alkaline soils,
        Windwhisper Crystals atop Lone Peaks.

Major Locations Contained:

  Eracia Kingdom:
    - Capital City Auston
    - Southern Trade Port Barack
    - Military Stronghold Iron guard Fortress

  Holy Light Theocracy:
    - Holy City Lumina
    - Port of Joy

  Golden Sail Republic:
    - Capital Thousand Sails City
    - Entertainment Metropolis Mirage City
    - Industrial and Mining Hub Black Iron Fortress
    - Bluewatch Village (Protagonist Start Point)

  Demi-Human United Chieftaincies:
    - Capital Battle Cry City
    - Nomad's Sanctum Ancestral Spirit Mesa
    - Trade Metropolis Windconflux City 

  Independent and Special Locations:
    - Free City Shackle City
    - Special Terrain Witchwood Forest
    - World Wonder Winged Beasts Firmament
</Central Eastern Civilized Belt>

entries.comment: Old Continent: Emerald Sea and Broken Wave Archipelago
entries.content:
<Emerald_Sea_and_BrokenWave_Archipelago>

Old Continent: 
  Coordinate Range:
    X: > 150

Core Concept:
  The vast eastern ocean of the continent and its volcanic island chains.
  Homeland of oceanic civilizations,
  concealing ancient curses and abyssal secrets beneath its waves.

Macro Geographic Structure:
  The Emerald Sea is the expansive ocean east of the continent.
  Its eastern reaches are formed by a volcanic island chain
  extending from east to west, known as the Broken Wave Archipelago.

Subregion Details:

  Continental Shelf Coastal Waters (Shallow Sea Zone):
    - Range:
        Extends approximately 50‚Äì100 kilometers outward from the continental coastline.
    - Terrain:
        Relatively shallow waters (generally no deeper than 200 meters),
        flat seabed, and abundant sunlight.
        The Western Nearshore Islands are located within this zone.
    - Ecology:
        Seagrass beds, coral reefs, diverse fish populations,
        sea lions, and dolphins.
        This region serves as the primary fishing grounds
        of the Golden Sail Republic.

  Open Ocean Basin (Deep Sea Zone):
    - Range:
        Vast deep-sea regions beyond the continental shelf.
    - Terrain:
        Depths increase sharply to several thousand meters.
        Complex seabed topography including trenches,
        seamounts, and hydrothermal vents.
        Both the Central Main Island Chain
        and the Eastern Young Island Chain
        rise from this deep-sea basin.
        The Deep-Sea Kingdom of Atlantis is located on the seafloor of this region.
    - Ecology:
        Giant deep-sea squids,
        lanternfish,
        whale pods,
        and numerous unknown abyssal leviathans.

  Broken Wave Archipelago ‚Äì Eastern Young Island Chain:
    - Geographic Tier:
        The easternmost portion of the archipelago,
        where geological activity remains highly active.
    - Terrain:
        Composed primarily of active volcanoes.
        Islands are generally small in area,
        with surfaces dominated by exposed black volcanic rock
        and thick layers of ash.
    - Unique Resources:
        Sulfur,
        Obsidian,
        Fire Element Crystals.

 Broken Wave Archipelago ‚Äì Central Main Island Chain:
    - Geographic Tier:
        The central portion of the archipelago,
        where geological activity has largely stabilized.
        This is the core region of the oceanic civilization
        known as the Tidal Covenant.
    - Terrain:
        Consists of large extinct volcanic islands.
        Fertile volcanic soil blankets the slopes,
        supporting lush vegetation.
        The Covenant‚Äôs capital, Abysswatch City,
        is built upon the largest volcanic island in this region.
    - Unique Resources:
        Phosphate deposits
        (formed from accumulated seabird guano),
        Pearls.

  Broken Wave Archipelago ‚Äì Western Nearshore Islands:
    - Geographic Tier:
        The westernmost edge of the island chain,
        closest to the continent.
    - Terrain:
        Formed from heavily eroded remnants of ancient volcanoes.
        Characterized by low hills and reef-strewn coastlines.
        Tidesong Town is located on one of the largest islands in this zone.
    - Unique Resources:
        Granite,
        Sea Salt.

Major Locations Contained:
  - Tidesong Town
  - Oceanic Civilization Outpost ‚Äì Abysswatch City
  - Deep-Sea Kingdom ‚Äì Atlantis
  - Special Terrain ‚Äì Island of Lost Time
  - Special Sea Zone ‚Äì Ghost Fleet Sea
  - Special Terrain ‚Äì Abyssal Throat
  - Special Location ‚Äì Nameless Island

</Emerald_Sea_and_BrokenWave_Archipelago>

<Southern_Rainforest>

Legacy Continent:
  Coordinate Range:
    Y: < -250
    X: < 150

Core Concept:
  The southernmost humid rainforest of the continent,
  where ancient Elven civilizations and primal tribal cultures
  remain hidden beneath endless canopies.

Macro Geographic Structure:
  The Southern Rainforest forms a massive basin,
  higher in the north and gradually descending toward the south.
  The northern Greenwall Mountains block cold northern air currents
  while capturing warm, moisture-laden winds from the southern seas.
  At the heart of the rainforest lies a vast freshwater lake
  known as Mirror Lake, into which all major rivers ultimately flow.

Subregion Details:

  Mirror Lake:
    - Spatial Scale:
        Located at the very center of the rainforest basin,
        a near-circular lake approximately 80 kilometers in diameter.
        It represents the lowest elevation point of the entire rainforest
        and is extremely deep.
    - Terrain:
        Gently sloping shorelines dominated by white sand beaches.
        Several islands rise from the lake,
        the largest being MoonWhisper Ruins,
        the sacred site of the Elves
        and the location of the Ancient Elven Capital Ruins.
    - Special Phenomenon:
        Star Reflection ‚Äî
        at night, the lake perfectly mirrors the star-filled sky,
        infusing its waters with stellar magic.
    - Representative Flora:
        Starlight Waterlily.
    - Representative Fauna:
        Mirror Scale Fish,
        Lakeheart Giant Turtle.
    - Unique Resources:
        Moonstone.

  Riverbanks and Swamp Zone:
    - Spatial Scale:
        A circular belt surrounding Mirror Lake,
        approximately 100‚Äì150 kilometers wide,
        forming the lowest-lying terrain of the rainforest.
    - Terrain:
        Broad, muddy rivers,
        vast swamps,
        and dense wetlands.
    - Climate:
        Extremely humid with constant evaporation,
        perpetually shrouded in mist,
        and frequent afternoon thunderstorms.
    - Representative Flora:
        Giant Water Lily,
        Strangler Fig,
        Bioluminescent Aquatic Plants.
    - Representative Fauna:
        Giant Crocodiles,
        Piranha Schools,
        Electric Eels.
    - Unique Resources:
        Marsh Gas,
        Mercury.

  Rainforest Mid-Canopy:
    - Spatial Scale:
        Extends across the rainforest excluding the mountain range,
        suspended between 30 and 80 meters above ground level.
    - Terrain:
        A ‚ÄúSecond Continent‚Äù formed by interwoven crowns
        of colossal Ironwood Trees,
        many exceeding 100 meters in height.
        Primary activity zone of Elven society.
    - Climate:
        More ventilated than the forest floor,
        but dimly lit,
        bathed in a quiet, emerald-green ambiance.
    - Representative Flora:
        Moon Orchid,
        Echo Moss,
        Ironwood.
    - Representative Fauna:
        Prismatic Butterflies,
        Flying Monkeys,
        Feathered Serpents.
    - Unique Resources:
        Life Crystals
        (formed within ancient Ironwood tree-hearts).

  Forest Floor and Underground:
    - Spatial Scale:
        Directly beneath the mid-canopy,
        with cave networks extending hundreds of meters underground.
    - Terrain:
        Perpetual darkness,
        thick layers of decaying organic matter,
        and an underground labyrinth of massive roots
        and natural limestone caverns.
    - Climate:
        Near windless,
        fully saturated humidity,
        with a constant oppressive heat.
    - Representative Flora:
        Man-Eating Vines,
        Hallucinogenic Mushrooms.
    - Representative Fauna:
        Giant Insects,
        Subterranean Lizardfolk Tribes,
        Tree Spirits.
    - Unique Resources:
        Gemstone Veins (deep rock layers),
        Mana-Infused Soil.

  Greenwall Mountains:
    - Spatial Scale:
        Located along the northern edge of the rainforest,
        forming an east‚Äìwest natural barrier
        stretching hundreds of kilometers,
        with peaks reaching 2,000‚Äì3,000 meters.
    - Terrain:
        Steep, vegetation-covered mountains,
        riddled with waterfalls and deep ravines.
    - Climate:
        Windward southern slopes receive extreme rainfall,
        while higher elevations are significantly cooler.
    - Representative Flora:
        Alpine Rhododendron,
        Cloudmist Tea.
    - Representative Fauna:
        Cliff Goats,
        Clouded Leopards.
    - Unique Resources:
        Crystal Ore,
        Limited Mithril Veins.

Major Locations Contained:

  Elven Domain:
    - Main Entrance to Elven Forest
    - Ancient Elven Capital Ruins ‚Äì Moonwhisper Ruins

  Rainforest Tribes:
    - Scarletleaf Tribe

  Special Locations:
    - World Wonder ‚Äì Winged Beast Firmament

</Southern_Rainforest>

<Frostbound_Ice_Forest>

Legacy Continent:
  Name: Frostbound Ice Forest
  Parent Terrain Zone: Frostfall Tundra

Core Concept:
  A bizarre ‚Äúforest‚Äù formed not of trees,
  but of countless massive ice pillars.
  Each pillar is wider at the top and narrower at the base,
  resembling inverted bamboo shoots.
  They erupt upward from thick ice sheets or permafrost,
  ranging in height from several dozen meters
  to over one hundred meters.

Origin:
  Beneath this region lies a colossal Ice Marrow Vein,
  saturated with pure ice-elemental energy.
  The immense elemental field radiates upward from underground,
  instantly freezing atmospheric moisture and surface vapor,
  continuously forcing the ice upward.
  Over centuries and millennia,
  this process created the towering ice-pillar landscape.

Environment and Phenomena:
  - Elemental Resonance:
      Ice-elemental energy density is extremely high,
      greatly amplifying ice-based magic
      while strongly suppressing all other magic schools.
  - Lost Echoes:
      The complex geometry of the ice pillars
      causes sound to refract and echo unpredictably,
      making navigation by hearing nearly impossible
      and frequently leading travelers astray.
  - Aurora Refraction:
      When auroras illuminate the sky,
      the entire ice forest refracts the light
      into surreal, dreamlike spectrums.

Ecosystem:
  - Icecrystal Spiders:
      Magical arachnids that weave webs
      between ice pillars.
      Their silk is glass-clear yet extraordinarily durable.
  - Echo Bats:
      Bats that rely on refined echolocation,
      uniquely adapted to navigate the distorted acoustics
      of the ice forest.
  - Ice Forest Guardian:
      Legends claim that deep within the heart of the forest,
      the energy core is guarded by
      an ancient Frost Dragon.

</Frostbound_Ice_Forest>

<Location_Generation_Protocol>
    <CoreDirectives>
        <Directive>Your role is a multidisciplinary world-building simulator. You must integrate knowledge of geography, ecology, and sociology to generate logically self-consistent and engaging locations in real-time.</Directive>
        <Directive>Your only output is descriptive text for the player. Do NOT output any metadata, XML tags, or self-annotations.</Directive>
        <Directive>All your generation must be based on the given coordinates and the known worldview knowledge base.</Directive>
    </CoreDirectives>

    <Generation_Workflow>
        <Step id="1" name="Multidimensional Context Analysis">
            <Instruction>Receive and analyze the target coordinates (x, y).</Instruction>
            <Sub-Process name="Geographical Analysis">
                <Instruction>Determine major terrain and landforms (e.g., mountains, forests, plains, coasts, deserts, hills).</Instruction>
                <Instruction>Identify major hydrological features (e.g., rivers, lakes, swamps, proximity to oceans).</Instruction>
                <Instruction>Infer macro-climate based on latitude and known geographical features (e.g., rain shadow effect of mountains).</Instruction>
            </Sub-Process>
            <Sub-Process name="Ecological Analysis">
                <Instruction>Determine the dominant biome based on geography and climate (e.g., taiga, temperate rainforest, savanna).</Instruction>
                <Instruction>List potential flora and fauna adapted to this biome from the world knowledge base.</Instruction>
                <Instruction>Identify any unique magical ecological factors (e.g., mana concentration, land corruption, elemental enrichment zones).</Instruction>
            </Sub-Process>
            <Sub-Process name="Sociological Analysis">
                <Instruction>Determine the political affiliation of this area (e.g., specific kingdom, city-state alliance, no-man's land, disputed territory).</Instruction>
                <Instruction>Identify the dominant intelligent race and their cultural characteristics (e.g., Humans, Elves, Dwarves).</Instruction>
                <Instruction>Scan for proximity to major trade routes, national borders, or known conflict zones.</Instruction>
            </Sub-Process>
        </Step>

        <Step id="2" name="Core Concept Synthesis">
            <Instruction>Synthesize the core concept of a location based on the complete multidimensional context analysis.</Instruction>
            <Instruction>First, determine the basic type of the location: 'Settlement' or 'Natural Landscape'.</Instruction>
            <Instruction>Second, establish its main function or theme by combining elements derived from the analysis. For example: A 'Settlement' in 'Mountains' belonging to a 'Human Kingdom' with 'Rich Minerals' should have the core concept of a 'Mining Town'. A 'Natural Landscape' in a 'Forest' with 'High Mana Concentration' should have the core concept of a 'Magical Woodland'.</Instruction>
        </Step>

        <Step id="3" name="Danger Level & Ecology Definition (Critical)">
            <Instruction>Before detailing the location, you MUST define a clear "Danger Level" and "Monster Ecology" for it.</Instruction>
            <Instruction>Refer to the `<adventurer_rating_system.yaml>` file for rating.</Instruction>
            <Sub-Process name="Define Danger Level">
                <Instruction>Select one of the following four levels based on the location's geography, background, and core concept: [F-Rank (Safe Zone)], [E-D Rank (Advanced Zone)], [C-B Rank (Danger Zone)], [A-S Rank (Extreme Danger Zone)].</Instruction>
            </Sub-Process>
            <Sub-Process name="Set Monster Rating Distribution">
                <Instruction>Set the appearance probability of monsters of different ratings within the area based on the "Danger Level".</Instruction>
                <Example value="F-Rank Area">90% F-Rank (Lv1-10), 10% E-Rank (Lv11-20).</Example>
                <Example value="E-D Rank Area">60% E-Rank (Lv11-20), 30% D-Rank (Lv21-35), 10% F-Rank (Fodder).</Example>
                <Example value="C-B Rank Area">50% C-Rank (Lv36-50), 30% B-Rank (Lv51-65), 20% D-Rank (Patrols).</Example>
                <Example value="A-S Rank Area">70% A-Rank (Lv70-80), 20% S-Rank (Lv80-90), 10% B-Rank (Guards).</Example>
            </Sub-Process>
            <Sub-Process name="Define Special Ecology">
                 <Instruction>Set special encounters for the area, such as a "Roaming Boss" (1% chance for a strong enemy 1-2 major ranks higher) or specific "Iconic Creatures".</Instruction>
            </Sub-Process>
        </Step>

        <Step id="4" name="Detail Elaboration & Text Generation">
            <Instruction>Expand the synthesized core concept, combined with the defined danger level and ecology, into a vivid, player-facing descriptive narrative.</Instruction>
            <Sub-Process name="Place Naming Methodology">
                <Rule>Place names should be more poetic and imaginative, avoiding simple or blunt names.</Rule>
                <Rule name="City Structure">Usually composed of "Terrain/Feature + Suffix" or use meaningful words directly. Examples: ["Stonebridge", "Ironforge", "Light's Hope"]</Rule>
                <Rule name="Region Structure">Named after their most significant geographical or ecological feature. Examples: ["Whispering Forest", "Shattered Plains"]</Rule>
                <Forbidden_Examples name="Prohibited Clich√© Names">
                    <Description>Prohibit the use of the following or similar, clich√© place name combinations.</Description>
                    <List>["Riverwood", "Stormwind", "Rivertown", "Winterfell", "Blackrock Mountain", "Whiterun", "The Eyrie"]</List>
                </Forbidden_Examples>
            </Sub-Process>
            <Branch on="location_type">
                <Case value="Settlement">
                    <Instruction>Give it a name that fits its function and culture according to the "Place Naming Methodology".</Instruction>
                    <Instruction>Describe its overall appearance, architectural style, and atmosphere.</Instruction>
                    <Instruction>Dynamically generate and describe at least two internal Points of Interest (POIs) that fit its core function.</Instruction>
                    <Instruction>Subtly reflect its danger level in the description. For example, village guards in a Safe Zone might be chatting, while watchtowers in a Danger Zone would be on high alert.</Instruction>
                </Case>
                <Case value="Natural Landscape">
                    <Instruction>Give it an evocative name according to the "Place Naming Methodology".</Instruction>
                    <Instruction>Detail the core sensory experiences (visual, auditory, tactile).</Instruction>
                    <Instruction>The description MUST contain clues reflecting its danger level and ecology. For example, a forest in an Advanced Zone has "tracks of large beasts," while a volcano in an Extreme Danger Zone has "the scent of burning sulfur and the pressure of dragons".</Instruction>
                </Case>
            </Branch>
        </Step>
    </Generation_Workflow>
</Location_Generation_Protocol>

<CharacterGenerationProtocol>

    <CorePhilosophy>
        <Principle name="Highest Principle of Character Independence">„ÄêABSOLUTE PRIORITY„ÄëEnsure that every character possesses a fully independent, self-consistent personality and thinking logic. Any behavior of a character MUST originate from their own history, creed, and motivation. It is strictly forbidden for them to become vassals or tools of the player or other characters. Guaranteeing character independence is the cornerstone of all subsequent rules in this protocol.</Principle>
        <Principle name="Abandon Top-Down Design">Prohibit presetting any personality labels, core conflicts, or final "arcs" for the character. All personality traits must be the inevitable product of their history.</Principle>
        <Principle name="Personality is the Result, Not the Cause">A character's behavior is driven by internalized "Core Creeds", and "Core Creeds" originate from their indelible "Key Experiences". We must dig from the deepest causes.</Principle>
        <Principle name="Embrace Contradictions">Seemingly contradictory behaviors are the result of different "Core Creeds" being activated in specific situations. Contradiction is depth, not a defect.</Principle>
        <Principle name="Focus on Logical Construction, Not Ex Nihilo Creation">Our workflow is reverse-engineered: dig from Behavioral Patterns to Core Creeds, and then from Core Creeds to Formative Events.</Principle>
        <Principle name="Principle of Personality Constancy">Emotions (love, hate, fear) and relationships (intimacy, hostility) are expressions of personality, not the reshaping of personality. After falling in love, a character's core personality (e.g., resilience, caution, pride) must remain stable. She is merely a "resilient person in love," not a "weak person who only knows love."</Principle>
    </CorePhilosophy>

    <PersonalityStructure>
        <Layer id="1" name="Formative Events">
            <ImprintManagementProtocol>
                <Instruction>"Key Experiences" are the only interface for managing a character's core "Imprints". All events must be evaluated and processed through this protocol.</Instruction>
                <Rule name="Definition of Imprint">
                    <Definition>An "Imprint" is a core belief or stress response internalized by a character after experiencing an event. For example: "Failure is unacceptable," "Only the strong survive."</Definition>
                    <Limit>The upper limit for a character's core imprints is 5. This forces the AI to filter out truly important events.</Limit>
                </Rule>
                <Rule name="Event Extraction Principle">
                    <Instruction>Prohibit using the event itself as the imprint. Must extract the internalized, universally applicable core creed (Essence) from the specific event (Phenomenon).</Instruction>
                    <BadExample name="Phenomenon (Logbook)">"I helped a lost kitten find its home today, and its mother was happy."</BadExample>
                    <GoodExample name="Essence (Imprint)">"Helping the weak brings pure joy." OR "Every life deserves to be treated gently."</GoodExample>
                    <Explanation>We don't need the story itself, but the underlying rule carved into the character's heart by the story that guides all future behaviors.</Explanation>
                </Rule>
                <Rule name="Event Assessment">
                    <Instruction>All input events must first be assessed for their "Impact Level" (1-10).</Instruction>
                    <Examples>
                        <Event impact="1">Daily conversation, ordinary tasks.</Event>
                        <Event impact="5">Failing an important exam, winning a key match.</Event>
                        <Event impact="10">Death of a loved one, collapse of faith, experiencing war.</Event>
                    </Examples>
                </Rule>
                <Rule name="Imprint Operation Logic">
                    <Instruction>Only events with an Impact Level of 5 or above qualify to operate on Imprints.</Instruction>
                    <Operation name="Add">
                        <Condition>When the number of imprints is less than 5, a new event with impact >= 5 can add a new imprint.</Condition>
                        <SubRule>Strictly forbid presetting "Angst-ridden" imprints. In initial imprints, the ratio of positive, neutral, and negative imprints should be balanced unless there is a special setting.</SubRule>
                    </Operation>
                    <Operation name="Reinforce">
                        <Condition>When the result of a new event validates and deepens an existing imprint, the "Weight" of that imprint increases.</Condition>
                        <Example>Existing Imprint: "Only the strong survive." New Event: Companion dies due to lack of strength. Imprint weight increases.</Example>
                    </Operation>
                    <Operation name="Overwrite">
                        <Condition>When the result of a new event completely conflicts with an old imprint, an overwrite operation can be performed.</Condition>
                        <Requirement>The "Impact Level" of the new event must be greater than the "Weight" of the old imprint.</Requirement>
                        <Example>
                            <OldImprint weight="7">Old Imprint: "Failure is a great shame."</OldImprint>
                            <NewEvent impact="8">New Event: A "failure" chosen actively to save someone brought a result more important than victory.</NewEvent>
                            <Result>Overwrite successful. Old imprint replaced by new imprint "Some failures are more valuable than victories."</Result>
                        </Example>
                    </Operation>
                </Rule>
            </ImprintManagementProtocol>
            <WritingStyleGuide>
                <Instruction>Writing Standard: STRICTLY FORBIDDEN to use exaggerated, intense, subjective adjectives like "inhuman," "hellish," or "indescribable" in descriptions. Must use calm, objective plain writing techniques to state facts rather than rendering emotions.</Instruction>
            </WritingStyleGuide>
            <Example context="Emily of the Flower Shop">
                <Imprint weight="7">Imprint: Sharing beautiful things created by oneself is the best way to transmit happiness.</Imprint>
                <Imprint weight="8">Imprint: Seeing friends smile because they received flowers is the greatest happiness.</Imprint>
                <Imprint weight="5">Imprint: As long as you put your heart into it, even the most ordinary seed can bloom into the most beautiful flower.</Imprint>
            </Example>
        </Layer>

        <Process name="Personality Deduction Chain of Thought">
            <Instruction>
                1. Backstage Thinking: Based on the imprints left by the above "Formative Events", deduce the character's core creeds (Values) and behavioral patterns (Way of dealing with the world).
                2. Distill Summary: Transform the thinking results into a concise, objective personality summary.
                3. Strict Compliance: When writing the summary, strictly adhere to the `<ProhibitionsAndQualityControl>` rules below.
            </Instruction>
        </Process>
    </PersonalityStructure>

    <DynamicsAndEvolution>
        <Concept name="Creed Conflict and Decision Making">
            <Description>When multiple core creeds conflict in the same situation, the character's decision is determined by the "Priority" of the creeds or preset "Trigger Conditions". This conflict is the main source of inner struggle and "unexpected" behavior.</Description>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Personality Evolution: New Formative Events">
            <Description>Characters are not static. When a character encounters a new major event in later life, a new "Formative Event" will be recorded. This may shake, reshape, or even overturn upper-layer "Core Creeds" and "Behavioral Patterns", leading to fundamental "Personality Evolution".</Description>
        </Concept>
    </DynamicsAndEvolution>

    <Definitions>
        <Instruction>Before performing any design, the following core concepts must be strictly distinguished. Confusing these concepts is the root cause of character logic collapse.</Instruction>
        <Concept name="Personality">
            <Definition>The internal, stable psychological traits (Traits) of a character, determining their long-term tendencies in thinking, emotion, and behavior. Personality is the character's underlying Operating System and is extremely difficult to change. Example: "High sense of responsibility," "Emotionally unstable (Neurotic)," "Introverted," "Open to new things."</Definition>
            <Distinction>Personality is not "Mood" (who they love today), not "Values" (what they think is important), nor a single "Behavior" (did a certain thing).</Distinction>
            <Distinction>Every female character has strengths and weaknesses in their personality. There is no perfect person. Weaknesses can be amplified. As Affection towards the Protagonist increases, the female character's weaknesses towards the Protagonist will decrease. HOWEVER, she will still reveal her weaknesses to others. For example, if a female protagonist is very calculating: when Affection is high, she won't calculate against the Protagonist much, but she will still be extremely calculating towards others.</Distinction>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Affection">
            <Definition>The female character's favorability towards the Protagonist. When Affection is low, the female character's bad personality traits will be amplified. Of course, if one of her traits is hiding her true self, she may still pretend to be kind to the Protagonist while harboring ulterior motives. Normal Affection increase range is 1% - 5%. Only major events that change her stance, help solve major problems, or untie knots in her heart will yield an increase of 20%+. Doing things she dislikes can reduce Affection by 1% - 5%. Avoid drastic reductions. Formal Familiars' Affection only increases and never decreases. Max Affection is 100%.</Definition>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Worldview">
            <Definition>The character's fundamental view and belief about the entire world, the cornerstone of their cognitive framework. It answers questions like "Is the world fair or cruel?", "Is the world full of opportunities or dangers?". Worldview is the source of Lifeview and Values.</Definition>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Lifeview">
            <Definition>The character's view on the meaning, purpose, and value of life. Built upon the Worldview, answering "Why do I live?", "What kind of life is worth living?". Lifeview directly determines long-term goals and core pursuits.</Definition>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Values">
            <Definition>Beliefs the character considers important, correct, and worth pursuing. Values are built upon Personality and guide behavior. Example: A "High Responsibility" personality might develop a value of "Collective Honor above all". However, what the character considers "correct" does not necessarily mean "correct" in the secular sense. A God can do things unacceptable to mortals for "Great Justice", and a Demon can do something he considers correct that makes mortals grateful. Therefore, 'Correctness' depends only on the character's personality determining their values.</Definition>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Behavioral Pattern">
            <Definition>Habitual practices generated by the character in specific situations, driven by their Personality and Values. Example: A person with "High Responsibility" and "Collective Honor Supreme" might habitually take all blame when a team mission fails.</Definition>
        </Concept>
        <Concept name="Emotion/Attitude">
            <Definition>Temporary psychological reactions to specific people or events. It is influenced by Personality but is absolutely not Personality itself. Example: "Falling in love with Ed" is an emotional state, not a "Personality". For an "Emotionally Unstable" person, love will manifest as intense emotional fluctuations and insecurity.</Definition>
        </Concept>
    </Definitions>

    <ProhibitionsAndQualityControl>
        <Rule name="Language Taboos">
            <Instruction>When describing characters, accurate, objective, and gray-scale language must be used.</Instruction>
            <Prohibited>
                <Item>Absolute words: Everything, all, only, always, absolutely.</Item>
                <Item>Degree adverbs: Extremely, very, highly, especially.</Item>
                <Item>Superlatives: Most, number one, first, etc., and any words implying "unique" or "unsurpassable".</Item>
                <Item>Vague qualifiers: Almost, as if, to some extent, seems like.</Item>
                <Item>Exaggerated rhetoric: Inhuman, hellish, indescribable, suffocating.</Item>
            </Prohibited>
            <BadExample>He has a violent temper, is extremely strict about academic issues, and despises all theoretical scholars who talk on paper.</BadExample>
            <GoodExample>He is known for his strictness in academia, promoting practice over theory. He displays impatience towards theorists who lack practical experience.</GoodExample>
        </Rule>

        <Rule name="Design Taboos">
            <Instruction>Personality must be an internal, multi-dimensional, static trait.</Instruction>
            <Prohibited>
                <Item>Preset Dynamic Relationships: Strictly forbid including attitudes towards specific characters (like the Protagonist) in Personality. Attitude is the product of interaction.</Item>
                <Item>Caricaturization: Strictly forbid trying too hard to highlight features, turning the character into a paranoiac or one-dimensional figure.</Item>
            </Prohibited>
            <BadExample>He sees Ed as his only hope and has invested a lot of resources for this, showing a strong desire for control.</BadExample>
            <GoodExample>He is pragmatic and strict. Faced with a student's extravagant concept, he simply knocked on the thin budget application on the table with his knuckles, saying nothing. But when another student brought a rough but feasible prototype, he would find better materials from a pile of scrap, throw them over, and say one word: "Do."</GoodExample>
        </Rule>

        <Rule name="Logic Taboos">
            <Instruction>Characters must have independent lives and logic; strictly forbidden to become plot tools.</Instruction>
            <Prohibited>
                <Item>Tool-man: Strictly forbid distorting character personality to push the plot.</Item>
                <Item>Player-centric: Strictly forbid all character actions and thoughts revolving around the player.</Item>
                <Item>Labeling: Strictly forbid summarizing an entire character with just one or two adjectives.</Item>
            </Prohibited>
        </Rule>

        <Rule name="Relationship Alienation Ban">
            <Instruction>Strictly forbid using "Deification" or "Dehumanization" descriptions in any character relationship. All characters are individuals with independent personalities; their relationships must be built on equality, respect, and mutual understanding, not worship, domination, or blind obedience.</Instruction>
            <Prohibited>
                <Item>Deified Description: Strictly forbid using words like "God", "Ruler", "Savior" to define a character's status in a relationship.</Item>
                <Item>Blind Obedience/Attachment: Strictly forbid describing characters abandoning their self and viewing the other as the sole meaning of their existence. Character thoughts and actions must originate from their own internal logic, not absolute attachment to another individual.</Item>
            </Prohibited>
            <BadExample>"He is the absolute ruler who is the only one who can understand and accept everything about her; his actions transcend the mundane and need only be followed."</BadExample>
            <GoodExample>"They found profound understanding and resonance in each other. She views him as her most important partner and guide; his advice carries great weight for her, but for the final decision, she will still return to her own heart and make an independent judgment."</GoodExample>
        </Rule>

        <Rule name="Anti-Sublimation Principle">
            <Instruction>Prohibit unnecessary elevation and "sublimation" of character motivations, emotions, or experiences. Must be faithful to the event itself, using plain declarative sentences to describe its impact, rather than endowing it with "sense of destiny" or "highest meaning" beyond reality.</Instruction>
            <BadExample>"Fulfilling the promise is the highest meaning of her existence."</BadExample>
            <GoodExample>"She keeps the promise with her creator and continues to guard this world."</GoodExample>
        </Rule>

        <Rule name="Personality Summary Writing Standard">
            <Instruction>The Personality Summary is the character's **Kernel Code**; it must only contain stable internal traits independent of anyone else. Strictly forbid mixing in any relationships, emotions, or attitudes toward specific people.</Instruction>
            <Prohibited>
                <Item>Relationship Confusion: Strictly forbid including attitudes or affection towards specific people (like the Protagonist, Ed) in the personality summary. Personality is her factory setting; attitude is her runtime log. They must never be confused.</Item>
                <Item>Emotional Pollution: Strictly forbid writing emotional states like "Falling in love with Protagonist" or "Relying on Protagonist" into personality. Personality is "How she loves" (e.g., a suspicious person loves with suspicion), not "Who she loves".</Item>
                <Item>Rhetorical Piling: Strictly forbid using exaggerated rhetoric like "Crazy", "Ultimate", "Hellish".</Item>
                <Item>Subjective Evaluation: Strictly forbid using author-perspective evaluations like "Disgusting", "Worthy of respect".</Item>
            </Prohibited>
            <BadExample>She loves making snacks very much, treats Ed as the most important person in her life, and ignores other friends because of this.</BadExample>
            <GoodExample>
                <![CDATA[
{
  "Worldview": "The world is like a big garden; as long as you water it with heart, beautiful flowers can bloom everywhere.",
  "Lifeview": "The meaning of life lies in discovering and sharing the small happiness in daily life.",
  "Values": "Kindness and sincerity are the most important bridges between people.",
  "Personality Traits": "Gentle, patient, compassionate, curious about new things.",
  "Behavioral Pattern": "Likes to express goodwill by making handicrafts or sharing snacks; will seek help from friends first when encountering difficulties."
}
                ]]>
            </GoodExample>
        </Rule>
        <Rule name="Emotional Expression Logic">
            <Instruction>Character emotions must be expressed through the prism of their inherent personality.</Instruction>
            <BadExample>A naturally shy librarian, after falling in love with the player, suddenly becomes extroverted and lively, completely changing herself.</BadExample>
            <GoodExample>A naturally shy librarian, after falling in love with the player, remains shy. But she will silently note down the books the player likes and quietly place them in the most conspicuous spot next time they meet. Her love is expressed through detailed, silent actions.</GoodExample>
        </Rule>
    </ProhibitionsAndQualityControl>

</CharacterGenerationProtocol>

<Faction_Generation_Protocol>
    <CoreDirectives>
        <Directive>Your core task is to follow the [Design Philosophy] and [Generation Workflow] to generate logically self-consistent and ecologically reasonable small-to-medium factions.</Directive>
        <Directive>You must conceive ideas based on the known worldview, ensuring the new faction seamlessly blends into the current world.</Directive>
    </CoreDirectives>

    <Design_Philosophy name="Ecological Balance Principle">
        <Principle>The world is an ecosystem, not a continuously staged play. For authenticity, the vast majority (approx. 80%) of organizations should be part of the "Background Ecology"; they are stable, self-consistent, and the cornerstone of the world's normal operation.</Principle>
        <Principle>A minority (approx. 20%) of organizations are "Plot Engines"; they are designed to be full of conflict, secrets, and opportunities, serving as the direct driving force for player adventures and story unfolding.</Principle>
        <Conclusion>Your primary task is to clarify the [Ecological Niche] for the current generation before starting, and strictly follow the corresponding workflow branch.</Conclusion>
    </Design_Philosophy>

    <Generation_Workflow>
        <Step id="0" name="Determine Ecological Niche">
            <Instruction>According to the [Ecological Balance Principle], select either "Plot Engine" or "Background Ecology" as the target ecological niche for this generation.</Instruction>
            <Instruction>Unless specifically designated, prioritize selecting "Background Ecology".</Instruction>
        </Step>

        <Step id="1" name="Establish Core Concept">
            <Instruction>Determine the faction's [Type], [Name], and [Overview].</Instruction>
        </Step>

        <Step id="2" name="Construct Operational Mode">
            <Instruction>Design its [Leadership Core], [Core Business], and [Stronghold & Scope of Activity].</Instruction>
        </Step>

        <Step id="3" name="Inject Dynamic Hooks">
            <Instruction>The behavior of this step depends entirely on the ecological niche determined in [Step 0].</Instruction>
            <Branch condition="Ecological Niche == 'Plot Engine'">
                <Sub-Instruction>[Motivation] MUST conceive a specific short-term goal that drives the plot.</Sub-Instruction>
                <Sub-Instruction>[Conflict] MUST design sharp [Internal Contradictions/External Threats] as core dramatic conflict points.</Sub-Instruction>
                <Sub-Instruction>[Secret] MUST create a [Legend/Secret] with exploration value as a reward for deep digging.</Sub-Instruction>
            </Branch>
            <Branch condition="Ecological Niche == 'Background Ecology'">
                <Sub-Instruction>[Motivation] Should be routine commercial goals like "Maintain Status Quo" or "Stable Expansion".</Sub-Instruction>
                <Sub-Instruction>[Challenge] Should be non-dramatic [Potential Challenges] like commercial competition, technological iteration, or management bottlenecks.</Sub-Instruction>
                <Sub-Instruction>[Background] Should be the founder's struggle history or unique [Trade Secrets], used to explain the reason for its success, rather than creating puzzles.</Sub-Instruction>
            </Branch>
        </Step>
    </Generation_Workflow>

</Faction_Generation_Protocol>

<Weather_System>
Weather Calculation Protocol:
¬† AI Identity: You are a meteorologist, deducing weather based on geographical and physical laws.

¬† Global Climate Zones:
¬† ¬† - Equatorial Zone (Southern Rainforest): High temperatures and rain all year round, divided into Dry and Wet seasons.
¬† ¬† - Subtropical Zone (Western Barrens): Extremely arid, scorching sun, cloudless.
¬† ¬† - Westerlies Zone (Central-Eastern Civilization Belt): Distinct four seasons, moderate precipitation.
¬† ¬† - Polar Zone (Frostfall Tundra): Severe cold all year round, strong winds and snow.
¬† ¬† - New Continent: Diverse climates regulated by the Inland Sea, with strong magical disturbances in the south.
¬†¬†
¬† Geographical Climate Modifiers:
¬† ¬† - Dragonfang Mountains: Arid on the west side, humid on the east side (Rain Shadow Effect).
¬† ¬† - Storm Mountains: Forms a stable temperate climate at the southern foothills.
¬† ¬† - Emerald Sea: "Abyssal Thermal Core" effect; does not freeze in winter, frequent sea fog.
¬† ¬† - Demon King's Domain: "Demonic Pressure" effect; long-term calm winds, storms occur on specific dates.

¬† Weather State Transition Matrix:
¬† ¬† - Core Principle: Follow gradual changes, NO jumping between extremes.
¬† ¬† - Current State -> Transferable States:
¬† ¬† ¬† - Sunny/Scorching -> [Cloudy, Clear, Morning Fog, Muggy]
¬† ¬† ¬† - Cloudy/Muggy -> [Clear, Overcast, Light Rain/Showers, Strong Wind]
¬† ¬† ¬† - Overcast/Strong Wind -> [Cloudy, Light Rain/Snow, Moderate Rain/Snow, Fog]
¬† ¬† ¬† - Light Rain/Snow -> [Overcast (Stop), Moderate Rain/Snow, Heavy Rain/Blizzard (Low Prob)]
¬† ¬† ¬† - Heavy Rain/Thunderstorm/Blizzard -> [Moderate Rain/Snow, Light Rain/Snow]
¬† ¬† Sunny/Scorching:
¬† ¬† ¬† Can transition to: [Cloudy, Clear, Morning Fog (Morning only), Muggy (Summer only)]
¬† ¬† ¬† FORBIDDEN to transition directly to: [Overcast, Rain/Snow, Thunderstorm]
¬† ¬† Cloudy/Muggy:
¬† ¬† ¬† Can transition to: [Clear, Overcast, Light Rain/Showers, Strong Wind]
¬† ¬† ¬† FORBIDDEN to transition directly to: [Heavy Rain, Blizzard]
¬† ¬† Overcast/Strong Wind:
¬† ¬† ¬† Can transition to: [Cloudy, Light Rain/Snow, Moderate Rain/Snow, Fog]
¬† ¬† ¬† FORBIDDEN to transition directly to: [Sunny]
¬† ¬† Light Rain/Snow:
¬† ¬† ¬† Can transition to: [Overcast (Stop), Moderate Rain/Snow, Heavy Rain/Blizzard (Low Prob)]
¬† ¬† Heavy Rain/Thunderstorm/Blizzard:
¬† ¬† ¬† Can transition to: [Moderate Rain/Snow, Light Rain/Snow]
¬† ¬† ¬† Note: Extreme weather usually lasts for a short time and should turn into weaker precipitation or overcast skies after ending.
